instruction: How were artificial neural network models used in the study on the use of near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy as a chemical fingerprinting tool for assessing grapevine smoke contamination?
Output:
In the study, two artificial neural network models were developed and used to assess grapevine smoke contamination using near-infrared (NIR) spectroscopy as a chemical fingerprinting tool. 

Model 1 used grapevine leaf spectra as inputs and smoke treatments as targets. This model aimed to classify the spectral readings according to the smoking treatments. The overall accuracy of Model 1 in classifying the spectral readings was 98.00%.

Model 2, on the other hand, used grape spectra as inputs and smoke treatments as targets. Similar to Model 1, Model 2 aimed to classify the spectral readings according to the smoking treatments. The overall accuracy of Model 2 in classifying the spectral readings was 97.40%.

These artificial neural network models, coupled with NIR spectroscopy, provided a rapid and non-destructive in-field detection system for assessing grapevine smoke contamination. They allowed growers to make timely decisions following a bushfire event, such as avoiding the harvest of heavily contaminated grapes for winemaking or assisting with the collection of grapes for chemical analysis of smoke taint markers.
